title: Trade offs in designing versatile log format
Description: How I designed a versatile log format and implemented it in Go

inline_content.Text: Description: How I designed a versatile log format and implemented it in Go

title: This article shows that when designing software even simple things are complicated and full of trade offs.

inline_content.Text: This article shows that when designing software even simple things are complicated and full of trade offs.

title: I wanted to log events to a file and I had several requirements for my design:

inline_content.Text: I wanted to log events to a file and I had several requirements for my design:

title: it should be simple and therefore easy to implement

inline_content.Text: it should be simple and therefore easy to implement

title: it should be human-readable

inline_content.Text: it should be human-readable

title: it should allow various types of events

inline_content.Text: it should allow various types of events

title: On the face of it, it's not a hard problem.

inline_content.Text: On the face of it, it's not a hard problem.

title: We can log sequential JSON objects. It allows various types of events. It's easy to implement (in the sense that there's a library in every language for the hard part of encoding/decoding JSON).

inline_content.Text: We can log sequential JSON objects. It allows various types of events. It's easy to implement (in the sense that there's a library in every language for the hard part of encoding/decoding JSON).

title: Oops, it's not particularly human-readable.

inline_content.Text: Oops, it's not particularly human-readable.

title: How about something like Apache server logs:

inline_content.Text: How about something like Apache server logs:

title: 127.0.0.1 - frank [10/Oct/2000:13:55:36 -0700] "GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0" 200 2326 "http://www.example.com/start.html" "Mozilla/4.08 [en] (Win98; I ;Nav)"

It's readable but doesn't really allow for different types of events. Implementing this format isn't particularly challenging but it's completely ad-hoc. To encode different kind of data I would have to write completely new formatter/parser.

inline_content.Text: It's readable but doesn't really allow for different types of events. Implementing this format isn't particularly challenging but it's completely ad-hoc. To encode different kind of data I would have to write completely new formatter/parser.

title: How about something more structured:

inline_content.Text: How about something more structured:

title:
ip: 127.0.0.1
request: GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0
status code: 200

content_resolved.code:
ip: 127.0.0.1
request: GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0
status code: 200

title: We can write a library that serializes key / value pairs and that gives us ability to write different kinds of events to the same file with generic code.

inline_content.Text: We can write a library that serializes key / value pairs and that gives us ability to write different kinds of events to the same file with generic code.

title: But hold on, how do we know when one event ends and another one starts?

inline_content.Text: But hold on, how do we know when one event ends and another one starts?

title: We must amend our format:

inline_content.Text: We must amend our format:

title:
ip: 127.0.0.1
request: GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0
status code: 200
---

content_resolved.code:
ip: 127.0.0.1
request: GET /apache_pb.gif HTTP/1.0
status code: 200
---

title: We're not there yet. We use newline to separate lines that encode a single key / value pair. What if the value has a newline in it?

inline_content.Text: We're not there yet. We use newline to separate lines that encode a single key / value pair. What if the value has a newline in it?

title:
body: hello fred
I'm writing to you...

content_resolved.code:
body: hello fred
I'm writing to you...

title: We could escape the value:

inline_content.Text: We could escape the value:

title: body: hello fred\nI'm writing to you...

content_resolved.code: body: hello fred\nI'm writing to you...

title: Escaping is not great. It requires changing the data, which is expensive and error prone.

inline_content.Text: Escaping is not great. It requires changing the data, which is expensive and error prone.

title: Furthermore, what if the value is really large? It won't be readable encoded on a single line.

inline_content.Text: Furthermore, what if the value is really large? It won't be readable encoded on a single line.

title: Let's amend our format to accommodate large values:

inline_content.Text: Let's amend our format to accommodate large values:

title:
body:+33
hello fred
I'm writing to you...

content_resolved.code:
body:+33
hello fred
I'm writing to you...

title: 33 is the size of the value. That way it doesn't require escaping (faster, simpler to implement), more readable and supports binary data (like images).

inline_content.Text: 33 is the size of the value. That way it doesn't require escaping (faster, simpler to implement), more readable and supports binary data (like images).

title: To formalize, key / value pair can be encoded in 2 ways:

inline_content.Text: To formalize, key / value pair can be encoded in 2 ways:

title: ${key}: ${value}\n
c

inline_content.Text: ${key}: ${value}\n

title: ${key}:+${sizeOfValue}\n${value}
c

inline_content.Text: ${key}:+${sizeOfValue}\n${value}

title: Let's revisit the idea of using a separator:

inline_content.Text: Let's revisit the idea of using a separator:

title:
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
---
ip: 10.0.0.2
request: GET /index.html HTTP/1.0
---

content_resolved.code:
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
---
ip: 10.0.0.2
request: GET /index.html HTTP/1.0
---

title: For delimiting records we can use the same tricks we used for encoding large values above:

inline_content.Text: For delimiting records we can use the same tricks we used for encoding large values above:

title:
36
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

content_resolved.code:
36
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

title: First line is size of data as a string, newline and followed by the size of the data.

inline_content.Text: First line is size of data as a string, newline and followed by the size of the data.

title: This is very generic framing. We could put anything we want frame that way. It could be a picture, a JSON-encoded data or our key / value format.

inline_content.Text: This is very generic framing. We could put anything we want frame that way. It could be a picture, a JSON-encoded data or our key / value format.

title: It's not yet quite right. Above we have logged an HTPP requests info and car info in the same file. How do we know what type of record did we read?

inline_content.Text: It's not yet quite right. Above we have logged an HTPP requests info and car info in the same file. How do we know what type of record did we read?

title: Let's amend our framing with optional name:

inline_content.Text: Let's amend our framing with optional name:

title:
36 httplog
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43 carinfo
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

content_resolved.code:
36 httplog
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43 carinfo
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

title: And finally let's add non-optional timestamp in
Unix Epoch
a
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time
format in milliseconds:

inline_content.Text: And finally let's add non-optional timestamp in
Unix Epoch
format in milliseconds:

title:
36 1553564864010 httplog
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43 1553564864115 carinfo
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

content_resolved.code:
36 1553564864010 httplog
ip: 10.0.0.1
request: GET / HTTP/1.0
43 1553564864115 carinfo
car: Toyota Corolla
year: 2018
price: 21000

title: Unlike name, which is optional, I decided timestamp is not optional. You can set it to 0 if you don't need it but for most logging needs you want a timestamp.

inline_content.Text: Unlike name, which is optional, I decided timestamp is not optional. You can set it to 0 if you don't need it but for most logging needs you want a timestamp.

title: Implementing the thing

inline_content.Text: Implementing the thing

title: This is not just theoretical exploration. I've implemented this format as a
Go package siser
a
https://github.com/kjk/siser

inline_content.Text: This is not just theoretical exploration. I've implemented this format as a
Go package siser

title: It took me 2 days to implement. It's just under 500 lines of code:

inline_content.Text: It took me 2 days to implement. It's just under 500 lines of code:

title:
$ wc -l reader.go record.go util.go writer.go
     167 reader.go
     196 record.go
      79 util.go
      57 writer.go
     499 total

content_resolved.code:
$ wc -l reader.go record.go util.go writer.go
     167 reader.go
     196 record.go
      79 util.go
      57 writer.go
     499 total

title: Not counting tests but I do have them because I need this to be rock solid.

inline_content.Text: Not counting tests but I do have them because I need this to be rock solid.

title: How fast is it? I benchmarked it against JSON encoding:

inline_content.Text: How fast is it? I benchmarked it against JSON encoding:

title:
BenchmarkSiserMarshal-12      	 1000000	      1136 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONMarshal-12       	 1000000	      1407 ns/op
BenchmarkSiserUnmarshal-12    	 5000000	       374 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONUnmarshal-12     	  500000	      3353 ns/op

content_resolved.code:
BenchmarkSiserMarshal-12      	 1000000	      1136 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONMarshal-12       	 1000000	      1407 ns/op
BenchmarkSiserUnmarshal-12    	 5000000	       374 ns/op
BenchmarkJSONUnmarshal-12     	  500000	      3353 ns/op

title: The benchmark is mostly to make sure that I didn't make a big perf mistake. It would be embarrassing to be slower than JSON encoding. As a side note: it's impressive how  fast JSON marshaling in Go standard library is.

inline_content.Text: The benchmark is mostly to make sure that I didn't make a big perf mistake. It would be embarrassing to be slower than JSON encoding. As a side note: it's impressive how  fast JSON marshaling in Go standard library is.

title: I'm moving all my logging to this format.

inline_content.Text: I'm moving all my logging to this format.

title: This is not only good for logging but also for very simple stores aka databases. The file can be seen as append-only database log and to update a record I just write a new entry.

inline_content.Text: This is not only good for logging but also for very simple stores aka databases. The file can be seen as append-only database log and to update a record I just write a new entry.

title: The roads not taken

inline_content.Text: The roads not taken

title: After reading this you might not be impressed. This design is clearly inspired by many others. All I did is put known things in a specific, but very familiar, way.

inline_content.Text: After reading this you might not be impressed. This design is clearly inspired by many others. All I did is put known things in a specific, but very familiar, way.

title: Simplicity is insidiously non-trivial. The design described here is a v2. First design used
c
for record separator, didn't have name and timestamp.

inline_content.Text: Simplicity is insidiously non-trivial. The design described here is a v2. First design used
for record separator, didn't have name and timestamp.

title: Only several months after first version I got enough insight to improve it.

inline_content.Text: Only several months after first version I got enough insight to improve it.

title: This is even more apparent when you look at mistake of others.

inline_content.Text: This is even more apparent when you look at mistake of others.

title: MIME is a format used for encoding e-mail messages. While being very close

inline_content.Text: MIME is a format used for encoding e-mail messages. While being very close

Root.title: Trade offs in designing versatile log format
